OI.open: I think I find it quite difficult to make the correct sounds when speaking, without first seeing the word written down (assuming it is written in characters I am familiar with)
Sometimes the spelling and the pronunciation differ and I'd rather hear the word first and then read it.
to ensure dont mishear, esoecially with similar letters, like v and f or m and n
speaking and listening is the first skills in a new language
It makes it easier for me to learn, I am a pretty visual learner
to correct hearing errors
it helps me sound it out loud, which helps me with pronunciation
and word recognition,
as well as with recall
For me, I find oral fluency much easier to reach than written.
I prefer to learn languages by speaking and hearing them, not writing (which I have done as well, with dead languages).
so many english words are spelt in different ways that dont always make it easy on first appearance
This clarifies any misconception with sounds, especially when the words are similar
hearing is most helpful first.
written and hering the word is more to process
specific_code: It is too much to process

OI.open: because you can then visualise the word as well
and maybe notice patterns in spellings if it is similar to a word you already know.
You can also make sure you are pronouncing it correctly if you see it. (if you can read)
Because some letters sound similar, it re-enforces you are hearing the correct sound
Because I'm quite a visual and textual learner and slightly deaf, so I rely more on what I see than what I hear.
Easier to concentrate on one aspect of the word first. ie just hearing it or just seeing it
specific_code: It is too much to process

OI.open: If you are a very visual learner
you can picture the word spelling when you say it
Helps embed in uour brain
to confirm youve heard the sounds correctly
to match the letters to the sounds
Learning the spelling of a word allows you to use it in writing. I find it frustrating being unsure about the spelling of a word when I want to use it in writing.
spellings provide a second sense to link the memory of the word to (sight as well as sound)
and can give you clues as to keaning which can also help memory.
It can give an indication of which sound you are lisening for in English - though not always
soliifies understanding of hearing the word, like a confirmation
